metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: List objects have a sort() method that will sort the list alphanumerically, ascending, by default:
content.html: List objects have a sort() method that will sort the list alphanumerically, ascending, by default:

content.code_html:
thislist = ["orange", "mango", "kiwi", "pineapple", "banana"]
thislist.sort()
print(thislist)

thislist = [100, 50, 65, 82, 23]
thislist.sort()
print(thislist)

content.text: To sort descending, use the keyword argument reverse = True :
content.html: To sort descending, use the keyword argument reverse = True:

content.code_html:
thislist = ["orange", "mango", "kiwi", "pineapple", "banana"]
thislist.sort(reverse = True)
print(thislist)

thislist = [100, 50, 65, 82, 23]
thislist.sort(reverse = True)
print(thislist)

content.text: You can also customize your own function by using the keyword argument key = function .
content.html: You can also customize your own function by using the keyword argument key = function.

content.text: The function will return a number that will be used to sort the list (the lowest number first):
content.html: The function will return a number that will be used to sort the list (the lowest number first):

content.code_html:
def myfunc(n):
  return abs(n - 50)

thislist = [100, 50, 65, 82, 23]
thislist.sort(key = myfunc)
print(thislist)

content.text: By default the sort() method is case sensitive, resulting in all capital letters being sorted before lower case letters:
content.html: By default the sort() method is case sensitive, resulting in all capital letters being sorted before lower case letters:

content.code_html:
thislist = ["banana", "Orange", "Kiwi", "cherry"]
thislist.sort()
print(thislist)

content.text: Luckily we can use built-in functions as key functions when sorting a list.
content.html: Luckily we can use built-in functions as key functions when sorting a list.

content.text: So if you want a case-insensitive sort function, use str.lower as a key function:
content.html: So if you want a case-insensitive sort function, use str.lower as a key function:

content.code_html:
thislist = ["banana", "Orange", "Kiwi", "cherry"]
thislist.sort(key = str.lower)
print(thislist)

content.text: What if you want to reverse the order of a list, regardless of the alphabet?
content.html: What if you want to reverse the order of a list, regardless of the alphabet?

content.text: The reverse() method reverses the current sorting order of the elements.
content.html: The reverse() method reverses the current sorting order of the elements.

content.code_html:
thislist = ["banana", "Orange", "Kiwi", "cherry"]
thislist.reverse()
print(thislist)

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What is a correct syntax for sorting a list?
content.html: What is a correct syntax for sorting a list?
